liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: YEAH. THE. GIRLS. Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso have been nominated for 2022-23 Women's Ballon d'or, which is awarded to the best female footballer in 2023. It's the first time two Australians have reached the shortlist for football's most prestigious individual award. Matildas captain and Chelsea star Kerr has been nominated every year since the Women's Ballon d'or was introduced in 2018, while it's Raso's first nomination. Spain and Barcelona midfielder Aitana Bonmati is the favourite, having recently claimed the UEFA Player of the Year award ahead of Kerr.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso nominated for Women's Ballon d'or

children.content: YEAH. THE. GIRLS.

props.alt: Hayley jumps on Sam's back as they celebrate.

children.content: Hayley Raso and Sam Kerr.
(Getty)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rolling Stones are returning with their first original album in 18 years. The band launched their 24th studio album Hackney Diamonds at a theatre in east London before unveiling the music video to the single Angry, starring actress Sydney Sweeney. This will be the Stones' first album without long-time drummer Charlie Watts who died in 2021. The band also hinted fans can expect collaborations with Stevie Wonder and Lady Gaga – when the full album's released on October 20.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rolling Stones announce release date for new album, unveil lead single

props.alt: The three remaining band members smile on stage.

children.content: Ronnie Wood, Mick Jagger, and Keith Richards.
(Scott Garfitt/Invision/AP)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The summer of 2023 was the hottest on record, according to data from the European Union Climate Change Service released on Wednesday. The three-month period from June through August surpassed previous records by a large margin, with an average temperature of 16.8 degrees Celsius (62.2F) — 0.66C above average. Last month was the also the hottest August on record globally, the third straight month in a row to set such a record following the hottest ever June and July, the EU said on Wednesday. "Global temperature records continue to tumble in 2023," Copernicus deputy head Samantha Burgess said. "The scientific evidence is overwhelming, we will continue to see more climate records and more intense and frequent extreme weather events impacting society and ecosystems, until we stop emitting greenhouse gases," Burgess said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Summer 2023 was hottest on record, scientists say

children.content: The summer of 2023 was the hottest on record, according to data from the European Union Climate Change Service released on Wednesday.
The three-month period from June through August surpassed previous records by a large margin, with an average temperature of 16.8 degrees Celsius (62.2F) — 0.66C above average.
Last month was the also the hottest August on record globally, the third straight month in a row to set such a record following the hottest ever June and July, the EU said on Wednesday.
"Global temperature records continue to tumble in 2023," Copernicus deputy head Samantha Burgess said.

"The scientific evidence is overwhelming, we will continue to see more climate records and more intense and frequent extreme weather events impacting society and ecosystems, until we stop emitting greenhouse gases," Burgess said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Transport Minister Catherine King is standing by her decision to reject a request from Qatar Airways to increase its flights into Australia, insisting it was in the national interest. Qantas lobbied the government against the decision, but Virgin and Qatar put reasons to the government about why it should go ahead. Meanwhile, five Australian women onboard a Qatar flight in 20-20 — who were forced to undergo invasive body examinations — encouraged the Ms King not to approve the flights. Yesterday it was confirmed Ms King sent a letter to the women involved in the incident the same day she denied Qatar's request. At a press conference this morning, she maintains the decision was in the national interest — but didn't expand on what "national interest" means. "As I've said repeatedly, I made this decision in the national interest, and there is no one factor that I will point to that swayed my decision one way or the other," she said. "In making this decision, I did have the national interest — not commercial interests — at play when I was making that decision. "I don't think that it helps for me to point to any one factor. We make decisions in the national interest all of the time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Transport minister stands by decision to reject Qatar Airways' flight request

children.content: Transport Minister Catherine King
is standing by her decision to reject a request from Qatar Airways to increase its flights into Australia, insisting it was in the national interest.
Qantas lobbied the government against the decision, but Virgin and Qatar put reasons to the government about why it should go ahead.
Meanwhile, five Australian women onboard a Qatar flight in 20-20 — who were forced to undergo invasive body examinations — encouraged the Ms King not to approve the flights.
Yesterday it was confirmed Ms King sent a letter to the women involved in the incident the same day she denied Qatar's request.
At a press conference this morning, she
maintains the decision was in the national interest
— but didn't expand on what "national interest" means.
"As I've said repeatedly, I made this decision in the national interest, and
there is no one factor that I will point to that swayed my decision
one way or the other," she said.
"In making this decision, I did have the national interest — not commercial interests — at play when I was making that decision.
"I don't think that it helps for me to point to any one factor. We make decisions in the national interest all of the time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASIC, the Australian financial regulator, has launched legal action against PayPal Australia over allegedly unfair business contract terms. The proceedings allege PayPal Australia's contracts with small business customers contained an "unfair" term that gave business account holders 60 days to notify PayPal of any errors or discrepancies in fees they had been charged, or accept them as accurate. "ASIC alleges the term is unfair because the effect of the term is to permit PayPal to retain fees it has overcharged or wrongly charged if the small business does not notify PayPal of the error within 60 days of the fee appearing in its account statement," the watchdog's statement said. ASIC's deputy chair Sarah Court said the legal action was about protecting the interests of small businesses. "We allege this term is unfair because it allows PayPal to escape the consequences of its own errors in overcharging small businesses, and places additional burdens on small businesses to detect and correct charging errors," she said. PayPal Australia has been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Financial regulator sues PayPal Australia for alleged 'unfair' contract term

business account holders 60 days to notify PayPal of any errors or discrepancies in fees they had been charged, or accept them as accurate

the effect of the term is to permit PayPal to retain fees it has overcharged or wrongly charged
if the small business does not notify PayPal of the error within 60 days of the fee appearing in its account statement," the watchdog's statement said.
ASIC's deputy chair Sarah Court
said the legal action was about
protecting the interests of small businesses
"We allege this term is unfair because it
allows PayPal to escape the consequences of its own errors
in overcharging small businesses, and places
additional burdens on small businesses
to detect and correct charging errors," she said.
PayPal Australia has been contacted for comment.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to Thursday, September 7 — and the ABC's markets and business blog. Let's start in the US, where Wall Street finished lower overnight after stronger than expected economic data stoked fresh inflation and interest rate concerns. The data in question was from the services sector, with the Institute for Supply Management seeing its non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index lifting to 54.5 last month — a six-month high, and slightly higher than the 52.2 expected Coupled with prices paid by service-sector businesses for inputs increasing, that has investors nervous that interest rates will remain higher. Traders are still broadly expecting the US Federal Reserve to keep rates on hold when it meets this month, but their bets on a pause in November fell below 47% — a tumble from the previous bet of 57%, according to CME Group's FedWatch Tool. This concern has also delayed expectations for interest rate cuts happening sooner rather than later. Chief investment officer at BMO, Carol Schleif, said the data showed a strong economy and inflation not coming down "as fast as the Fed would need to start cutting rates any time in the foreseeable future ". That's also followed comments made earlier in the day by the Boston Fed's President Susan Collins, who remarked the US central bank needed to "proceed carefully" with its next steps in monetary policy. So, where does that leave us here in Australia? Well, according to the futures market, a weaker start on the ASX, for one. We can also expect the market to be sensitive to more interest rate and inflation thinking coming out of our own central bank today. RBA governor Philip Lowe is making what is widely expected to be his last public speech in the top job this afternoon at a lunch in Sydney, before he hands over to Michele Bullock at the end of next week. Still with me? Great — grab a coffee, settle in, and let's get this show on the road as we rapidly approach the weekend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Local market set for weak start after interest rate fears send Wall Street lower

Coupled with prices paid by service-sector businesses for inputs increasing, that has investors nervous that
interest rates will remain higher
Traders are still broadly expecting the US Federal Reserve to
keep rates on hold when it meets this month
, but their bets on a pause in November fell below 47% — a tumble from the previous bet of 57%, according to CME Group's FedWatch Tool.
This concern has also delayed expectations for interest rate cuts happening sooner rather than later.
Chief investment officer at BMO,
Carol Schleif
, said the data showed a strong economy and inflation not coming down "as fast as the Fed would need to start
cutting rates any time in the foreseeable future
That's also followed comments made earlier in the day by the
Boston Fed's President Susan Collins
, who remarked the US central bank needed to "proceed carefully" with its next steps in monetary policy.
So, where does that leave us here in Australia? Well, according to the futures market, a
weaker start on the ASX
, for one.
We can also expect the market to be sensitive to more interest rate and inflation thinking coming out of our own central bank today.
RBA governor Philip Lowe
is making what is widely expected to be his

Still with me? Great — grab a coffee, settle in, and let's get this show on the road as we rapidly approach the weekend.
